<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="background:#EBEBEB;border-collapse:collapse;font-family:Times New Roman;width:100.0%;">
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="100%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:100.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:3.0pt 0pt;text-align:center;"><!-- SET mrlHTMLTableFull --><!-- SET mrlNoTableShading --><font size="3" style="font-size:12.0pt;">THE COMMITTEES OF THE BOARD<a name="TheCommitteesOfTheBoard_035557"></a></font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 20.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">In 2006, the
Board maintained five (5) standing committees. The five standing committees are
the Compensation Committee, Environment, Safety and Technology Committee,
Finance and Investment Committee, Financial Audit Committee, and the Nominating
and Corporate Governance Committee. The Board has determined that each of the
members of the Compensation Committee, Environment, Safety and Technology
Committee, Finance and Investment Committee, Financial Audit Committee, and
Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee meets the standards of &#147;independence&#148;
established by the NYSE. The Board has determined that each of the members of
the Financial Audit Committee also meets the independence standards for audit
committee members adopted by the SEC. A description of each Board committee is
set forth or referred to in the following paragraphs.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Compensation Committee<a name="CompensationCommittee_031212"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The members of
the Compensation Committee are Kristina M. Johnson, Philip A. Odeen (Chairman)
and Charles O. Rossotti. Information about the Compensation Committee is
contained in &#147;Information About our Compensation Committee and Nominating and
Corporate Governance Committee&#148; beginning on page&nbsp;23 of this proxy
statement. The Compensation Committee operates under the Charter of the
Compensation Committee adopted and approved by the Board. A copy of the
Compensation Committee&#146;s Charter appears on the Company&#146;s web site
(www.aes.com). A copy of the Charter may also be obtained by sending a request
to the Office of the Corporate Secretary, The AES Corporation, 4300 Wilson
Boulevard, Arlington, VA 22203. The Compensation Committee met six (6) times in
2006.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Environment, Safety and Technology Committee
(the &#147;<i>EST Committee</i>&#148;)<a name="EnvironmentSafetyAndTechnologyCom_031214"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The EST
Committee monitors the environmental and safety compliance of the Company and
its subsidiaries; reviews and approves the scope of the Company&#146;s internal
environmental and safety compliance audit programs to consider the adequacy and
appropriateness of the programs being planned and performed; and reviews and
considers technology developments applicable to the industry and the Company&#146;s
businesses. The members of the EST Committee are Kristina M. Johnson, John A.
Koskinen (Chairman), and Philip Lader. The EST Committee operates under the
Charter of the Environment, Safety and Technology Committee adopted and approved
by the Board. A copy of the Charter appears on the Company&#146;s web site
(www.aes.com). A copy of the Charter may also be obtained by sending a request
to the Office of the Corporate Secretary, The AES Corporation, 4300 Wilson
Boulevard, Arlington, Virginia 22203. The EST Committee met four (4) times in
2006.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Finance and Investment Committee<a name="FinanceAndInvestmentCommittee_031217"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Finance and
Investment Committee focuses on the evaluation of strategic plans, potential
investments, budgets, proposed equity and/or debt offerings and is also available
to provide advice and assistance to Company management on a more frequent basis
than the regularly scheduled meetings of the Board. The members of the Finance
and Investment Committee are Richard Darman (Chairman), John H. McArthur,
Sandra O. Moose and Philip A. Odeen. The Finance and Investment Committee
operates under the Charter of the Finance and Investment Committee adopted and
approved by the Board. A copy of the Charter appears on the Company&#146;s web site
(www.aes.com). A copy of the Charter may also be obtained by sending a request
to the office of the </font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">8</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='8',FILE='C:\fc\141132233904_D11624_2138183\6350-1-cc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 21 13:23 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Corporate
Secretary, The AES Corporation, 4300 Wilson Boulevard, Arlington, Virginia
22203. The Finance and Investment Committee met five (5) times in 2006.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Financial Audit Committee (the &#147;<i>Audit Committee</i>&#148;)<a name="FinancialAuditCommitteetheauditCo_031220"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Board has a
separately designated standing Audit Committee established in accordance with Rule
10A-3 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (the &#147;Exchange Act&#148;) and New
York Stock Exchange Rule 303A.06. The members of the Audit Committee are John
H. McArthur (Chairman), John A. Koskinen, Charles O. Rossotti, and Sven
Sandstrom. The Audit Committee is responsible for the review and oversight of
the Company&#146;s performance with respect to its financial responsibilities and
the integrity of the Company&#146;s accounting and reporting practices. The Audit
Committee, on behalf of the Board, also appoints the Company&#146;s independent
auditors, subject to stockholder ratification, at the Annual Meeting. The Audit
Committee operates under the Charter of the Financial Audit Committee adopted
and approved by the Board. A copy of the Charter appears on the Company&#146;s web
site (www.aes.com). A copy of the Charter may also be obtained by sending a
request to the office of the Corporate Secretary, The AES Corporation, 4300
Wilson Boulevard, Arlington, Virginia 22203. Our Board has determined that all
members of the Audit Committee are independent within the meaning of the SEC rules&nbsp;and
under the current listing standards of the NYSE. The Board has also determined
that each member of the Audit Committee<b>  </b>is an Audit
Committee Financial Expert within the meaning of the SEC rules&nbsp;based on,
among other things, the experience of such member described above. Finally, the
Board has determined that each member of the Audit Committee is &#147;financially
literate&#148; as required by the NYSE. The Audit Committee met eleven (11) times in
2006.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee<a name="NominatingAndCorporateGovernanceC_031222"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Nominating
and Corporate Governance Committee provides recommendations for potential nominees
for election to the Board, establishes compensation for Directors, and also
considers governance and social responsibility issues relating to the Board and
the Company. The members of the Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee
are Philip Lader (Chairman), Sandra O. Moose and Sven Sandstrom. Nominees for
Director are selected on the basis of, among other things, experience,
knowledge, skills, expertise, integrity, ability to make independent analytical
inquiries, understanding the Company&#146;s global business environment and
willingness to devote adequate time and effort to Board responsibilities so as
to enhance the Board&#146;s ability to oversee and direct the affairs and business
of the Company. In certain instances, we use a third party to assist in
identifying potential nominees. The Nominating and Corporate Governance
Committee also considers potential nominations for Director provided by
Stockholders and submits any such suggested nominations, when appropriate, to
the Board for approval. Stockholder nominees are evaluated using the criteria
described above. Stockholders wishing to recommend persons for consideration by
the Committee as nominees for election to the Company&#146;s Board can do so by
writing to the Office of the Corporate Secretary of the Company at 4300 Wilson
Boulevard, Arlington, Virginia 22203. Any such stockholder nomination
recommendation should provide the nominee&#146;s name, biographical data and
qualifications. Any such recommendation also must be accompanied by a written
statement from the person recommended for nomination of his or her consent to
be named as a nominee and, if nominated and elected, to serve as a Director. The
By-laws also contain a procedure for stockholder nomination of Directors. (See &#147;Stockholder
Proposals and Nominations for Director&#148; set forth on page&nbsp;59 of this proxy
statement.)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Nominating
and Corporate Governance Committee operates under the Charter of the Nominating
and Corporate Governance Committee adopted and approved by the Board. A copy of
the Charter appears on the </font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">9</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='9',FILE='C:\fc\141132233904_D11624_2138183\6350-1-cc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 21 13:23 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Company&#146;s web
site (www.aes.com). A copy of the Charter may also be obtained by sending a
request to the Office of the Corporate Secretary, The AES Corporation, 4300
Wilson Boulevard, Arlington, Virginia 22203. The Nominating and Corporate
Governance Committee met five (5)&nbsp;times in 2006.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Director Compensation.</font></i></font><i>&nbsp;&nbsp; </i>The Nominating and Corporate
Governance Committee periodically reviews the level and form of compensation
paid to Directors, including the compensation program&#146;s underlying principles. Under
the Corporate Governance Guidelines, a Director who is also an officer of AES
is not permitted to receive additional compensation for service as a Director. In
reviewing and determining the compensation paid to Directors, the Committee
considers how such compensation relates and compares to director compensation
of companies of comparable size, which operate in a comparable industry and/or
have equivalent complexity. The Committee&#146;s review includes looking at both
direct and indirect forms of compensation to our Directors, including any
charitable contributions made by the Company to organizations with which Directors
are affiliated. The Executive Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary
assists the Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee with its review of
our director compensation program. The General Counsel&#146;s office conducts
research on other companies&#146; director compensation practices and provides the Committee
with a benchmarking analysis of those practices against the Company&#146;s program. Neither
the General Counsel nor the Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee
retain an independent compensation consultant to assist with recommending or
determining director compensation. Any changes to the director compensation
program are recommended by the Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee to
the Board for consideration and approval.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Nominating
and Corporate Governance Committee may form subcommittees and delegate to such
subcommittees such power and authority as the Committee deems appropriate and
in compliance with law.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">10</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='10',FILE='C:\fc\141132233904_D11624_2138183\6350-1-cc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 21 13:23 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="background:#EBEBEB;border-collapse:collapse;font-family:Times New Roman;width:100.0%;">
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="100%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:100.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="font-size:9.5pt;margin:3.0pt 0pt;text-align:center;"><!-- SET mrlHTMLTableFull --><!-- SET mrlNoTableShading --><font size="3" style="font-size:12.0pt;">EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION<a name="ExecutiveCompensation_035629"></a></font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 19.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">COMPENSATION DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<a name="AesCompensationDiscussionAndAnaly_031909"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Executive
Compensation Philosophy<a name="ExecutiveCompensationPhilosophy_031909"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 2.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">In all areas of our business, our policies
seek to maximize long-term value for our stockholders. Consistent with this
philosophy, we believe that stockholders benefit from compensation policies
that attract the highest caliber people and retain and motivate these
individuals. The Compensation Committee is responsible for designing, reviewing
and administering our executive compensation program (the &#147;Program&#148;). The
Program is designed to achieve the following objectives:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 2.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>link executive performance
to the achievement of our financial and operational performance objectives;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 2.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>align executive
compensation with the interests of our stockholders;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 2.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>support our business plans
and company objectives; and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>optimize our investment in
labor costs by maintaining compensation arrangements that not only drive
performance but are competitive and are valued by our employees, including the
named executive officers.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 2.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">To achieve these objectives, the Program
relies on the following components of total compensation:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 2.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>base salary;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 2.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>cash-based, short-term
incentives under our Performance Incentive Plan;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 2.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>cash-based, medium-term
incentives under our 2003 Long-Term Compensation Plan (&#147;LTC Plan&#148;) in the form
of performance units; and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>equity-based, long-term
incentives under our LTC Plan in the form of restricted stock units and stock
options.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Compensation Committee varies the allocation among these four
components of compensation so that the most senior executives in the Company,
including the Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer and the three
other executive officers and former executive officer named in the Summary
Compensation Table on page&nbsp;24 of this proxy statement (the &#147;named
executive officers&#148;), who have the greatest influence over our performance, are
awarded compensation that has a significant portion highly dependent upon Company
and individual performance. The Program is also designed to ensure that
compensation awards vest in a manner that rewards consistency in performance
over time.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">We believe that our Program, as currently structured, is consistent
with the objectives of our compensation philosophy. However, our philosophy and
our Program may evolve over time in response to factors such as market
conditions, legal requirements or other factors, including subjective factors
not currently known to us.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Targeted
Compensation</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Program targets setting overall compensation for each named
executive officer in the middle range of total compensation for executives
holding comparable positions in both our peer group of companies (the &#147;Peer
Group&#148;) and a broad set of similarly sized general industry and energy
companies. Our Program and each of its components is benchmarked against
compensation programs used by S&amp;P&nbsp;500 companies, as well as the
programs of our Peer Group.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:18.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">11</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='11',FILE='C:\Fc\1415586771_P66533CHE_2137229\6350-1-ce.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 21 05:58 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">To develop the Peer Group for our 2006 compensation, our senior
management generated a list of companies with whom we compete for executive
talent in the energy industry. The companies in the Peer Group have executives
with backgrounds relevant to our business. The list was reviewed by our outside
compensation consultants, who then, based on their review of our industry,
suggested changes to the Peer Group which were then discussed with our
management. The Peer Group includes CMS Energy, Calpine Corporation, Duke
Energy, Dynegy, Edison International, FPL Group, NRG Energy, Pacific Gas&nbsp;&amp;
Electric, Reliant Resources, Southern Company, and TXU Energy.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Compensation Committee determines total compensation in the first
quarter of each year based on available data. In 2006, the Compensation
Committee reviewed both 2004 proxy statement data for the Peer Group as well as
2005 survey data. The Compensation Committee, with the assistance of our
outside compensation consultants, made comparisons with similarly-situated
executives in Peer Group companies based upon criteria such as type of
position, business unit, career level, geographic region and company size. The
Compensation Committee also reviewed survey data supplied by our outside
compensation consultants in order to accurately reflect our competition for
certain executive positions which do not necessarily require industry-specific
experience (such as finance). The Program is designed to target energy industry
market data for industry specific positions and the general industry survey
data for functional or non-industry-specific positions, to ensure that the Company
remains competitive in the markets where we compete for executive talent.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">When determining total compensation for each named executive officer,
the Compensation Committee reviews &#147;tally sheets,&#148; which demonstrate total
compensation for the named executive officers. The tally sheets also review the
value of long term compensation assuming different performance outcomes for the
named executive officers. The Compensation Committee conducts this analysis
looking forward for several years to ensure that compensation paid to the named
executive officers is appropriate for these different company performance
scenarios. If compensation is not appropriate, the Compensation Committee makes
adjustments to the long term compensation awarded to each named executive
officer at the time of grant.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Although much of this analysis is based upon market data that provides
an objective basis to evaluate our compensation policies, some adjustments are
made based on subjective factors such as our views about the external market
place, the degree of difficulty of a particular assignment, the individual&#146;s
experience, the tenure of the individual in the role, and the individual&#146;s future
potential.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Additional information regarding the Compensation Committee&#146;s processes
and procedures in determining executive officer compensation, including the
role of the Chief Executive Officer and other executive officers, is contained
in &#147;Information About our Compensation Committee and Nominating and Corporate
Governance Committee&#148; on page&nbsp;23 of this proxy statement.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 9.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Allocation
among Components of Compensation<a name="AllocationAmongComponentsOfCompen_031923"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">After the overall targeted compensation has been established for each
named executive officer, compensation is allocated among base salary and short,
middle and long-term incentive compensation so that an executive&#146;s deviation
from the median of total compensation, as compared to similarly situated
executives in the Peer Group, is determined by individual and company
performance. If individual and company performance exceed the pre-established
performance measures, executives are compensated above the median of the Peer
Group. Conversely, executives are compensated below the median of the Peer
Group if individual and company performance is below the pre-established performance
measures. The types of information used to evaluate performance and the data
used to determine competitive compensation levels are the same for our named
executive officers as they are for our other executive officers.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:18.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">12</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='12',FILE='C:\Fc\1415586771_P66533CHE_2137229\6350-1-ce.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 21 05:58 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="line-height:11.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The importance
that the Program places on at-risk, performance-based compensation is shown by
the allocation of the target level of overall compensation awarded to the named
executive officers for 2006 among the various compensation elements of the
Program. For the Chief Executive Officer, the base salary target is 10%-15%,
the typical bonus target is 15%-20%, and the typical LTC target is 65%-75%.
For the other named executive officers, the base salary target is 20%-25%,
the typical bonus target is 15%-20%, and the typical LTC target is 55%-65%.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:11.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 9.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Compensation for AES Executives<a name="CompensationForAesExecutives_031926"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;line-height:11.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 9.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Base Salary</font></i></p>

<p style="line-height:11.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Program
targets base salaries for our named executive officers generally at or below
the median of the survey data provided by our compensation consultants. Base
salaries reflect current practices within a named executive officer&#146;s specific
market and geographic region and among executives holding similar positions in
the Peer Group. In addition to these factors, the base salary for a named
executive officer could be higher or lower, depending on a number of more
subjective factors, including the executive&#146;s experience, the executive&#146;s
sustained performance, the need to retain key individuals, recognition of roles
that are larger in scope or accountability than standard market position; and
market/competitive differences based upon a specific location.</font></p>

<p style="line-height:11.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The base salary
amounts paid to our named executive officers in 2006 are contained in the &#147;Salary&#148;
column of the Summary Compensation Table on page&nbsp;24 of this proxy
statement.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;line-height:11.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 9.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Performance Incentive Plan</font></i></p>

<p style="line-height:11.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:9.5pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">The Program provides named executive officers with an annual cash
incentive </font>to reward short-term individual performance. At the
2006 Annual Meeting of Stockholders, our stockholders approved The AES
Corporation Performance Incentive Plan (the &#147;Performance Incentive Plan&#148;),
which is available to our US-based employees, including the named executive
officers. The Compensation Committee&#146;s specific objectives with the Performance
Incentive Plan are to promote the attainment of our significant business
objectives; encourage and reward management teamwork across the Company; and
assist in the attraction and retention of employees vital to our success.</font></p>

<p style="line-height:11.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Performance
Incentive Plan links annual cash incentive payments to performance based on
factors that are drivers of our success&nbsp;&#151; including individual,
operational, safety, and financial goals&nbsp;&#151; and also reflect annual
incentives paid by other companies for comparable positions. Other
considerations include an executive&#146;s leadership skills, the difficulty of his
or her assignments, and the prospects for retaining the named executive officer.
These awards are not guaranteed.</font></p>

<p style="line-height:11.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 2.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The target annual cash incentive award for each named executive officer
is assessed and approved annually and ranges from 80 to 150 percent of base
salary, depending on an individual&#146;s specific job responsibilities. The award
paid in a previous year is not a factor in determining the current year award. Because
the amount of the award actually paid is based on the attainment of Company and
individual performance goals, the Performance Incentive Plan payment for a
specific named executive officer could be zero or as much as twice the target
payment. For 2006, awards for all plan participants (including the named
executive officers) were based on the following performance goals:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;line-height:11.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 1.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>40&nbsp;percent on meeting
cash flow targets;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;line-height:11.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 1.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>25&nbsp;percent on meeting
performance improvement and cost reduction targets;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;line-height:11.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 1.0pt 30.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>25&nbsp;percent on
achieving individual objectives; and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;line-height:11.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>10 percent on safety
performance.</p>


 <p style="margin:18.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">13</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='13',FILE='C:\Fc\1415586771_P66533CHE_2137229\6350-1-ce.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 21 05:58 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">If these performance goals are <i>not</i> fully
achieved at year end, the annual awards are paid according to the percentage of
the goals that were met. If threshold performance goals are not met, no payment
is made. Performance goals may also be exceeded, which could make the payment
under the annual award higher than the target. The Compensation Committee has
the discretion to reduce the amount of any annual award if it concludes that a
reduction is necessary or appropriate. The Compensation Committee cannot increase
the amount of any award intended to be performance-based compensation under Section
162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (the &#147;Code&#148;).</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The level of achievement of each performance goal is confidential, has
not been publicly disclosed, and the Compensation Committee has determined that
disclosure of the levels of such goals would cause competitive harm to the Company.
When the Compensation Committee set performance goals, the Compensation
Committee intended for performance at target to be a challenging, but
attainable, goal. The Compensation Committee also believed, at the time the
performance goals were set, that performance at a level above the target was achievable
but a stretch goal.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The threshold, target and maximum pay-out levels<b>  </b>of
the Performance Incentive Plan awards for each named executive officer are
shown in the &#147;Estimated Future Payouts Under Non-Equity Incentive Plan Awards&#148;
columns of the Grants of Plan-Based Awards Table on page&nbsp;26 of this proxy
statement.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">2006 Performance
Incentive Plan Awards</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">For 2006, Company performance on cash flow targets was above the target
performance level for the Performance Incentive Plan. Specifically, 120% of the
2006 cash flow target was met.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Company performance on performance improvement and cost reductions was
below the target performance level for the Performance Incentive Plan. Specifically,
90% of the 2006 performance improvement and cost reduction target was met.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Company performance on safety met the minimum threshold, but was below
the target performance level for such measure. Specifically, 80% of the 2006
safety target was met.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;font-style:normal;font-weight:normal;">Considering these
performance results as compared to performance targets, the named executive
officers (excluding Barry Sharp who was not eligible to receive a 2006 actual
or target bonus) received an average bonus of 124% of the 2006 target amount,
when consideration for performance of their personal objectives was measured</font></i></b><font style="font-weight:normal;">.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 2.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">For Paul Hanrahan, the CEO, the following
accomplishments were considered in determining that 145% of his 2006 individual
performance targets were met:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 1.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The commencement of construction
on our 600MW Maritza Coal Fired Power Plant in Bulgaria;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 1.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The acquisition of Transelect,
a domestic transmission development company;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 1.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The commencement of operations
at our 121MW wind generation facility at Buffalo Gap I in Texas;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 1.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The commencement of construction
of 233MW additional wind generation capacity at Buffalo Gap II;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 1.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The successful secondary equity
offering of Gener Stock in Chile;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 1.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The trend of performance improvement
since 2003;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 1.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The commencement of operations
at our 1200MW combined cycle gas turbine facility in Cartagena, Spain; and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;line-height:11.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The implementation of a plan
to enhance our finance capability, including significantly increased staffing
and improved training.</p>


 <p style="margin:18.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">14</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='14',FILE='C:\Fc\1415586771_P66533CHE_2137229\6350-1-ce.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 21 05:58 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="line-height:11.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Performance
Incentive Plan awards paid out to the named executive officers for 2006 are set
forth in the &#147;Non-Equity Incentive Plan Compensation&#148; column of the Summary
Compensation Table on page&nbsp;24 of this proxy statement.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;line-height:11.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">2003 Long-Term Compensation Plan</font></i></p>

<p style="line-height:11.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The AES
Corporation 2003 Long-Term Compensation Plan (the &#147;LTC Plan&#148;) is available to
all AES employees, including the named executive officers (subject to local
labor laws). In 2006, approximately 1,900 AES employees in 17 countries
received awards under the LTC Plan.</font></p>

<p style="line-height:11.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 2.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Cash and equity-based awards under the LTC Plan link individual
compensation with long-term value creation and our stock performance. During
2006, the following factors were considered in granting long-term compensation
awards to the named executive officers: (1) the level of equity-based
compensation paid to executives holding comparable positions in the Peer Group,
(2) individual or personal performance and future potential, and (3) Company
performance. For 2006, the Program included a mix of long term incentive awards
under the LTC Plan. All 2006 annual grants to named executive officers under
the LTC Plan were allocated as follows:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;line-height:11.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 1.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>50% in the form of Performance
Units (&#147;PUs&#148;);</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;line-height:11.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 1.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>25% in the form of Restricted
Stock Units (&#147;RSUs&#148;) (plus a risk related premium of 10% of additional RSUs);
and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 5.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>25% in the form of
nonqualified Options.</p>

<p style="line-height:11.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The
Compensation Committee has the discretion to amend the terms of any LTC plan
award after it has been awarded, but not if such amendment would impair the rights
of the holder of the award.</font></p>

<p style="line-height:11.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Program is
designed to strike a balance between the objectives of market value creation
and underlying economic performance by allocating 50% of LTC Plan in awards
which can be settled in stock (RSUs and Options) and 50% of LTC Plan awards in
awards which settle in cash (PUs).</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;line-height:11.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">2006 LTC Awards</font></i></p>

<p style="line-height:11.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Paul Hanrahan&#146;s
LTC Plan grant in February 2006 recognized his long-term contribution to AES
and the effectiveness of his leadership. Victoria Harker joined the Company as
Chief Financial Officer in January 2006 and received her first LTC Plan award
at that time. The award recognized her past experience and potential contributions
to AES, and reflected the market for newly appointed chief financial officers
of comparable companies. William Luraschi&#146;s LTC Plan award recognized his
ongoing contribution to AES and the Company continuity he provides in his
executive position. Andres Gluski and Haresh Jaisinghani, who recently left the
Company, were appointed to their executive positions at the beginning of 2006
and their LTC Plan awards reflected their promotion to their new roles and
market data for new hires holding comparable positions at companies in the Peer
Group.</font></p>

<p style="line-height:11.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Information
regarding the amounts and values of the LTC Plan awards is contained in the
Summary Compensation Table and the Grants of Plan-Based Awards Table on pages&nbsp;24
and 26 of this proxy statement. A description of the terms of the awards is
contained in &#147;Narrative Disclosure Relating to the Summary Compensation Table
and Grants of Plan-Based Awards Table&#148;&#160;
beginning on page&nbsp;27 of this proxy statement.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;line-height:11.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Performance Units (PUs)</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">PUs are performance-based awards that reward efficient generation of
cash over a rolling three-year period. They use a cash generation metric to
measure the net cash we generate by increasing revenue, reducing costs, and
improving productivity, which we consider a significant source of stockholder
value creation, and which directly links compensation with the performance of
our business during the measurement period. The payment </font></p>


 <p style="margin:18.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">15</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='15',FILE='C:\Fc\1415586771_P66533CHE_2137229\6350-1-ce.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 21 05:58 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">made, if any, under each PU depends upon the level of the PU&#146;s cash
generation metric achieved over the three year measurement period.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Since PUs have a three-year performance period, the PUs we granted in
2006 have a measurement period ending in 2008 and, if paid out, will be paid in
2009. The PU payments made for the 2004&nbsp;&#150; 2006 performance period, were
made under PUs granted in 2004<b>.</b></font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The following table illustrates possible payouts under the PUs granted
in 2006 to the named executive officers, assuming these PUs fully vest. If less
than 90% of the cash generation metric (the &#147;Cash Value Added&#148; or &#147;CVA&#148;) is
achieved for the three year measurement period, no payments will be made under
these PUs. If CVA levels are achieved at the 90% level, each PU has a value of
$0.50; if CVA levels are achieved at greater than 90% and less than 100% of the
CVA target, or greater than 100% and less than 120% of the CVA target, the PU payout
will be determined based on a straight-line interpolation, subject to a maximum
value of $2.00 per unit. There is no increase in PU payments above the maximum
value per unit if the CVA level is above 120%.</font></p>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 5.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">VALUE OF PERFORMANCE UNITS BASED ON 2006 CASH
VALUE ADDED TARGET<a name="ValueOfPerformanceUnitsBasedOn200_072912"></a></font></b></p>

<div align="center" style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

  </td>
  <td width="97" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:72.9pt;">

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 11.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="line-height:11.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Although the
targeted CVA during the specific three year performance period is determined at
the time the PU is granted, pre-established adjustments may be made to the CVA
target based on changes to the Company&#146;s portfolio, such as an asset
divestiture or sale of a portion of equity in a subsidiary. In addition, an
external financial consultant is engaged at the end of each year to assist
management and the Compensation Committee in calculating CVA. The target level
of CVA for the PUs granted in 2006 is confidential, has not been publicly
disclosed, and the Compensation Committee has determined that disclosure of its
target level would cause competitive harm to the Company. <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">At the time the Compensation Committee established
the 2006 PU awards, </font>the Compensation Committee intended for performance
at the target level to be a challenging, but attainable, goal. It is our policy
to grant PUs during the first quarter of each year at the Compensation
Committee&#146;s first regularly scheduled meeting for the year. We may also grant
PUs to an executive officer at the time he or she is hired or promoted to his
or her position of an executive officer.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:18.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">16</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='16',FILE='C:\Fc\1415586771_P66533CHE_2137229\6350-1-ce.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 21 05:58 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Payout of PU Awards Granted in 2004</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The PUs granted
in 2004 reached maturity at the end of 2006 and vested PUs were paid to
participants in March&nbsp;2007. The payout was based on our performance during
the three-year period of 2004-2006. During that period, the Company&#146;s
performance against its CVA target was above the predetermined target. Therefore,
payout of these units was at $1.1076 per unit, slightly above the initial value
of 1.00 per unit.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The payment of
the 2004 PU awards is reflected in the &#147;Non-Equity Incentive Plan Compensation&#148;
column of the Summary Compensation Table on page&nbsp;24&nbsp; of this proxy
statement.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Restricted Stock Units (RSUs)</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">A restricted
stock unit represents the right to receive a single share of AES common stock
or cash of equivalent fair market value. The RSUs granted to the named
executive officers in 2006 will vest in equal installments over a three year
period commencing on the first anniversary of the grant date if: (i)&nbsp;the
executive continues to be employed by AES on each such date; and (ii)&nbsp;(A)&nbsp;the
total stockholder return (&#147;TSR&#148;) of AES, measured by the appreciation in stock
price and dividends paid, exceeds the TSR of the S&amp;P&nbsp;500 Index for the
three-year vesting period, or (B)&nbsp;the TSR of AES is positive, the
S&amp;P&nbsp;500 Index is positive, and the TSR of AES is within 5 percent of
the TSR of the S&amp;P&nbsp;500 Index (subject to the Compensation Committee&#146;s
discretion to choose that the RSUs should not vest in such circumstance). Once
RSUs vest, a named executive officer must continue to hold the RSUs for an
additional two years before the named executive officer receives stock or cash
for the RSUs.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">It is our
policy to grant RSUs during the first quarter of each year at the Compensation
Committee&#146;s first regularly scheduled meeting for the year. We may also grant
RSUs to an executive officer at the time he or she is hired or promoted to his
or her position as an executive officer.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Payout of 2004 RSU Awards</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The first grant
of RSU awards under the LTC Plan vested at the end of 2006 as our TSR exceeded
the TSR of the S&amp;P 500 over the 2004-2006 measurement period. Our TSR
was 133%, while the TSR of the S&amp;P&nbsp;500 Index was 28%. Payout of these RSUs
will be made as soon as administratively practicable in 2009.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Vesting of the
2004 RSU awards is reflected in the Option Exercises and Stock Vested table on page&nbsp;33
of this proxy statement and additional information regarding the awards is set
forth in the Nonqualified Deferred Compensation Table (and its accompanying
narrative) beginning on page&nbsp;34 of this proxy statement.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Stock Options</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">An Option
represents an individual&#146;s right to purchase shares of AES common stock at a
fixed exercise price after the option vests. An Option only has value if our
stock price exceeds the exercise price of the stock option after it vests. Options
vest in equal installments over a three year period commencing on the first
anniversary of the date the Option is granted, provided that the named executive
officer continues to be employed by AES on such date. Options may also be used
in specific cases, such as in recruiting an executive and to attract high
caliber people. For example, on January&nbsp;23, 2006, the Board provided our
Chief Financial Officer with a sign-on LTC Plan Option grant. The grant was
valued using the closing market price of our stock on January&nbsp;23, 2006.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">17</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='17',FILE='C:\Fc\1418555697_P66507CHE_2137302\6350-1-cf.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 21 08:55 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">It is our
policy to grant Options to our executive officers during the first quarter of
each year at the Compensation Committee&#146;s first regularly scheduled meeting for
the year. We may also grant Options to an executive officer at the time he or
she is hired or promoted to his or her position as an executive officer. It is
our policy to grant Options to our executive officers at an exercise price
equal to the fair market value of our common stock (e.g., the closing price) on
the day of the Board meeting at which the recommendation of the Compensation
Committee are approved. In the case of Options granted at the time of hire or
promotion, it is our policy to grant them at an exercise price equal to the
fair market value on the grant date. All Options granted to our named executive
officers in 2006 adhered to these policies.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">In connection
with an internal accounting review of share-based long term compensation, we
reviewed our historical practices with respect to the award of share-based long
term compensation and determined that not all of our past awards to our
executive officers complied with these policies. The review determined that
with respect to annual grants made in the 1999 to 2001 period, the exercise
price was based on the lowest prices during the four day period during which
the Compensation Committee meetings were held.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">In 2003, AES
became an early adopter of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;123, which
requires that companies account for the cost of Options. Historically, AES used
Black-Scholes to determine the value of stock options. In 2006, the Board
determined that a forward looking market approach is the most appropriate method
for determining the volatility used in the Black Scholes calculation. The Company
now accounts for share-based compensation under Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;123R.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Perquisites and Other Benefits<a name="PerquisitesAndOtherBenefits_033551"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Consistent with
the Program&#146;s objectives, the named executive officers are eligible to participate
in company-sponsored health and welfare benefit and retirement programs to the
same extent as other non union U.S. employees, other than the Restoration
Supplemental Retirement Plan. The Restoration Supplemental Retirement Plan
provides supplemental retirement benefits to our eligible named executive
officers and other AES individuals to make up for the fact that participant and
company contributions under our 401(k)&nbsp;retirement plan are limited due to
restrictions imposed by the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (the &#147;Code&#148;)<b>.</b></font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Program
generally does not rely on perquisites to achieve its objectives. However, we
have a corporate apartment near our Arlington, Virginia&#160; headquarters, which is available to certain
AES employees. In addition, our Chief Executive Officer is entitled to use a
driver and company vehicle. Each perquisite is treated as taxable income to the
beneficiaries.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Information
regarding the value of the perquisites AES provided to its named executive
officers in 2006 is contained in the &#147;All Other Compensation&#148; column of the
Summary Compensation Table on page&nbsp;24 of this proxy statement. Additional
information regarding the Restoration Supplemental Retirement Plan is contained
in &#147;Narrative Disclosure Relating to the Nonqualified Deferred Compensation Table&#148;<b>  </b>beginning on page&nbsp;36 of this proxy statement.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Severance and Change in Control Arrangements<a name="SeveranceAndChangeOfControlArrang_033554"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Under the
Program, reasonable &#147;change in control&#148; and severance benefits are provided to
our named executive officers and certain other employees. In the case of our
named executive officers, the Compensation Committee believes these benefits
reflect the competitive marketplace for executive talent and are in line with
similar </font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">18</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='18',FILE='C:\Fc\1418555697_P66507CHE_2137302\6350-1-cf.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 21 08:55 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">arrangements of
companies with executives in comparable positions. Our change in control and
severance benefit arrangements with the named executive officers and certain other
employees recognize that our employees have built AES into the successful
enterprise it is today.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The purpose of these change in control
arrangements is to:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>ensure that the actions and
recommendations of our senior management with respect to a possible or actual
change in control are in the best interests of AES and its stockholders, and
are not influenced by their own personal interests concerning their continued
employment status after the change in control; and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:9.5pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:9.5pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>reduce
the distraction regarding the impact of an actual or potential change in
control on the personal situation of the named executive officers and other
employees.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Board,<b>  </b>upon the recommendation of the Compensation Committee,
approved employment agreements with our Chief Executive Officer and Chief
Financial Officer and, in 2006, adopted a new Severance Plan, which defined the
severance benefits for our US-based, non-union employees who have completed one
year of service. Since they have employment agreements, Mr.&nbsp;Hanrahan and Ms.&nbsp;Harker
do not participate in the Severance Plan. Additionally, the PU, RSU and Option
award agreements also contain change in control provisions.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">More detailed
information about the employment agreements, Severance Plan and award
agreements is contained in &#147;Narrative Disclosure Relating to the Summary
Compensation Table and Grants of Plan-Based Awards Table&#148; beginning on page&nbsp;27
of this proxy statement and &#147;Potential Payments Upon Termination and Change in
Control&#148; beginning on page&nbsp;38 of this proxy statement.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Employment Agreements</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">For competitive
reasons, the Compensation Committee determined that the Chief Executive Officer
and Chief Financial Officer should have employment agreements. Each of these
agreements is in line with the Program&#146;s compensation guidelines. The
agreements provide, among other matters, that if we terminate an executive&#146;s
employment without &#147;cause&#148; or the executive terminates his employment for &#147;good
reason,&#148; the executive will be entitled to the sum of his or her annual base
salary and target bonus for the year of employment termination multiplied by a
factor (of two, in the case of our Chief Executive Officer, and of one, in the
case of our Chief Financial Officer). If we terminate an executive&#146;s employment
without cause or the executive terminates for good reason within two years
following a change in control, the executive will receive, among other payments
and benefits, the sum of annual base salary and target bonus for the year of
employment termination multiplied by a factor (of three, in the case of our
Chief Executive Officer and of two, in the case of our Chief Financial Officer).
To protect our business interests, each of the agreements further provides that
AES will not be required to make any payments under those circumstances until
the executive executes a release of claims against AES. The definitions of
&#147;cause&#148;, &#147;good reason&#148; and &#147;change in control&#148; are contained in &#147;Potential Payments
upon Termination or a Change in Control&#148; beginning on page&nbsp;38 of this
proxy statement.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Additionally,
the employment agreements contain confidentiality, and two-year non-competition
and non-solicitation provisions to protect our business interests by preventing
these executives from disrupting our business, by competing, soliciting our
employees or customers, or disparaging AES during employment and
post-employment.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">19</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='19',FILE='C:\Fc\1418555697_P66507CHE_2137302\6350-1-cf.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 21 08:55 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Severance Plan</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Severance
Plan provides the named executive officers (other than our Chief Executive
Officer and Chief Financial Officer) and other eligible employees with payments
and benefits, including certain tax reimbursements and gross up benefits, in
the event their employment is involuntarily terminated under certain
circumstances. In such cases, participants in the Severance Plan are entitled
to, among other payments and benefits, one year&#146;s annual base salary plus the target
bonus for the year of employment termination. An action by AES is required for
a person to be involuntarily terminated under the plan. Additionally,
participating named executive officers are entitled to severance benefits in
the event of a change in control if they are <i>not</i>
offered continued employment in similar positions following a change in control.
To protect our business interests, the Severance Plan further provides that no
payments or benefits will be made thereunder until the terminated employee
executes a written release of claims against us. At our discretion, such
release may also contain such non-competition, non-solicitation and
non-disclosure provisions as we may consider necessary or appropriate.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Vesting of Awards Upon Change in Control</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Consistent with
the stockholder-approved LTC Plan, the Compensation Committee determined to
include change in control provisions in each of the PU, RSU and Option award
agreements. Upon a &#147;change in control,&#148; the unvested portion of the PUs, RSUs,
and Options will vest. The purpose of this accelerated vesting is to ensure
that we retain our key executives prior to and up to the change in control.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Tax Deductibility of Pay<a name="TaxDeductibilityOfPay_033608"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 8.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The Compensation Committee has considered the impact of the applicable
tax laws with respect to compensation paid under our plans, arrangements and
agreements. In certain instances, applicable tax laws impose potential
penalties on such compensation and/or result in a loss of deduction to AES for
such compensation.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">The tax
objectives and policies described below are subject to change by the
Compensation Committee, generally or in specific instances.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Section&nbsp;409A<a name="Section409a_033609"></a></font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Participation
in, and compensation paid under, our plans, arrangements and agreements may, in
certain instances, result in the deferral of compensation that is subject to
the requirements of Section 409A of the Code. To date, the U.S. Treasury
Department and Internal Revenue Service have issued only preliminary guidance
regarding the impact of Section 409A of the Code on AES&#146;s plans, arrangements
and agreements. Generally, to the extent that our plans, arrangements and
agreements fail to meet certain requirements under Section 409A of the Code,
compensation earned thereunder may be subject to immediate taxation and tax
penalties. We intend our plans, arrangements and agreements to be structured
and administered in a manner that complies with Section&nbsp;409A of the Code.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Section&nbsp;162(m)</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">With certain
exceptions, Section 162(m) of the Code limits our deduction for compensation in
excess of $1&nbsp;million paid to certain covered employees (generally our
Chief Executive Officer and four next highest-paid executive officers). Compensation
paid to covered employees is not subject to the deduction limitation if it is </font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">20</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='20',FILE='C:\Fc\1418555697_P66507CHE_2137302\6350-1-cf.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 21 08:55 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">considered &#147;qualified
performance-based compensation&#148; within the meaning of Section 162(m) of the
Code. While the Compensation Committee considers the tax impact of any
compensation arrangement, the Compensation Committee evaluates such impact in
light of overall compensation objectives of the Program. Accordingly, the
Compensation Committee may approve non-deductible compensation if the
Compensation Committee believes it is in the best interests of our stockholders.
Additionally, if any provision of a plan or award that is intended to be
performance-based under Section&nbsp;162(m)&nbsp;of the Code, is later found to
not satisfy the conditions of Section 162(m), our ability to deduct such
compensation may be limited.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">Change in Control Tax Gross-Up</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">If a change in control
of AES causes compensation, including performance-based compensation such as Performance
Incentive Plan or LTC Plan awards, to be paid or result in accelerating the
vesting, a disqualified individual could, in some cases, be considered to have
received &#147;parachute payments&#148; within the meaning of Section&nbsp;280G and Section&nbsp;4999
of the Code. Pursuant to Section 4999, a disqualified individual can be subject
to a 20% excise tax on excess parachute payments. Similarly, under Section&nbsp;280G
of the Code, AES can be denied a deduction for excess parachute payments. The
employment agreements with our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial
Officer and our Severance Plan provide that, if it is determined that any
payment or distribution by AES to or for the executive&#146;s benefit would
constitute an &#147;excess parachute payment,&#148; AES will pay to the disqualified
person a gross-up payment, so that the net amount retained by the disqualified
person, after deduction of any excise tax imposed under Section&nbsp;4999 of
the Code and other taxes, will be equal to the payments or distribution we were
required to make. Gross-up payments will not be deductible by AES. We included these
gross-up provisions in each of the employment agreements and in the Severance
Plan after a review of market practices.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.5pt;">21</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='21',FILE='C:\Fc\1418555697_P66507CHE_2137302\6350-1-cf.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 21 08:55 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
